scene.text: The car has finally stopped.
A car door opens.
Cold air rushes in, carrying with it the acrid stench of tobacco.
scene.speak: Achoo!
Get out of the car.
Oh.
scene.text: I subconsciously reach for the right door, only to find it closed.
scene.speak: Tsk. Your left! Left!
scene.text: The man grunts impatiently.
Obediently, I feel my way towards the other side of the car, bent over like a shrimp.
Fearing that my head would strike the door frame, I dare not straighten my back till I have taken two or three steps out of the car.
Not that I have a choice. What kind of person puts a black bag over someone's head …?
scene.speak: Move.
scene.text: The source of the voice grabs my arm, and without warning wrenches me forward. He is rather strong. Must be quite a burly chap.
Thump.
The sound of a car door slamming behind me, the sound of a starting engine.
scene.speak: Ah!
scene.text: A momentary lapse of focus, and I slip, falling to the ground like an idiot.
scene.speak: Ya fool, watch where ya going!
scene.text: If only I could actually see where I'm going.
The ground feels sodden, and the air wafting from the cold earth saps what little heat remained inside the legs of my trousers.
And so I walk, for how long I do not know.
My surroundings grow quieter and quieter. I vaguely hear the mournful hooting of owls.
It feels …
… No, they're not planning to “dispose” of me, are they?
After all, I'm an important “specimen”, so they wouldn't dare …
Wait.
In front of me, it sounds like someone is writing or scribbling on something.
scene.speak: … You may go back now.
scene.text: A female voice. Calm to the point of apathy. She doesn't sound very old. Perhaps a secretary of some sort.
scene.speak: Yes, Miss.
scene.text: The big hand latched onto my arm finally releases its grip.
I hear the flapping sound of a windbreaker, then the sound of footsteps slowly fading away.

scene.speak: Greenwich Mean Time, October 20, 22:57 — Thank you for your hard work, little lab rat.
Ah!
scene.text: Before I could even prepare myself, the hood on my head is suddenly whisked away with a 'swoosh'.
The drawstring elastic near the mouth of the hood had scraped violently against my nose. Now it stings.
scene.speak: Quiet.
scene.text: The messy-haired girl calmly commands me.
scene.speak: Follow me.
scene.text: She doesn't even give me the chance to get a proper look at her face.
She too knows that I have nowhere else to run.
A university campus. Harsh light from street lamps scatter off the bitumen, casting eerie shadows. I see pale lighting from a building up ahead, and it reminds of those terrible experiments.
As I walk, unable to stop, I begin to imagine myself as that desperate, pathetic figure fleeing for my life.
Fingers chewed raw.
Clothes torn to shreds.
Hysterically screaming.
Deliriously waving my hands about —
To be eventually shot down with a tranquiliser gun.
Or worse.
“Where you shall hear the howls of desperation,”
“and see the ancient spirits in their pain,”
“as each of them laments his second death — ”

remark.p: The quotation recalled by our protagonist is from Dante's “Divine Comedy” (Mandelbaum translation, Inferno Canto I.)

scene.speak: Don't be afraid. This place is different from the other laboratories.
scene.text: … She sees through me, straight to the anxiety within my heart.
scene.speak: Imperial Institute, Lab 42.
scene.text: She speaks, as if to herself —
scene.speak: Welcome home.
scene.text: Home?

scene.speak: Sit.
scene.text: The girl points to the sofa in the entrance hall.
scene.speak: Tea? Or coffee?
I recommend tea. The air in London is terrible.
Ein-Stein.
scene.text: She suddenly and solemnly speaks in German. Ein … Stein … “One Stone”?
scene.speak: Doctor, Einstein — Lieserl Albert Einstein.
scene.text: She points to herself, and then to me.
scene.speak: Your name?
… Omega 1. It's in my files.
Ω1 is not a human name.
… Then I don't have one.
How inconvenient.
scene.text: She shakes her head.
Even so, I can't do anything about that. After all —
scene.speak: … Welt. W.E.L.T.
Eh?
I feel this name is just right for you.
… Any name would do.
scene.text: “Ω” = “W”. “Welt” = “World”. Indeed, as an outcast of the world, to have such a name would be most amusing.
scene.speak: Now then, let's go through your physical checkup, Welt.
… Okay.
scene.text: Once again, I'll need to put on a lot of electrodes — perhaps a blood draw, or even a bone marrow biopsy. Well, I'm used to it all by now.
scene.speak: No, no need to get up. Just stay put.
Show me your soul.
Oh …
… Eh? S-Soul??
Take off your shoes and socks. I need to thoroughly examine your sole.
— What for?!
It's getting very late, we should finish up and rest soon.
… Huh?!
One can precisely and intuitively determine the state of someone's health by looking at their sole. Also, the inspection process is rather quick —
— Just grab a toothbrush and brush you up a bit, that should do it.
Wait …
… You mean, we can just calmly waltz off to bed after that?!
Correct. Your comprehension skills are remarkable.
… That doesn't make any sense!
Indeed.
… Huh?
Seeing Welt so depressed, Dr Einstein decided she'd tell a joke to lift his spirits.
scene.text: What the hell is wrong with this “doctor”?
scene.speak: You'll sleep in Room 105 over there.
scene.text: The girl points down a corridor to the side.
scene.speak: I live upstairs.
… Oh.
Good night. You can forget your past identity as a little lab rat.
scene.text: She walks away, without a single backward glance.
Leaving behind a “little lab rat”, rooted to the floor, dumbfounded.

text.p: The man now named “Welt” couldn't understand what just happened. Ever since the day he started forming memories again, nobody else had so casually given him such a baffling degree of freedom — even though “the day he started remembering" was not that long ago.

It was this same season, three years ago, when he first opened his eyes to a scene of chaos. Unfamiliar men and women were inspecting him, asking him all sorts of questions, questions that one would only ask a lost child..
“What is your name?”
“Where do you live?”
“What is your nationality?”

It was a strange feeling — you undoubtedly knew all the answers, yet you could not “congeal” or solidify those answers in your brain. It was as if all the neurons that wove the sea of your memories were fried.
“I don't know”
This was the one response that the young man could muster.

He could still remember how to speak — yet he didn't know whether this was something he should be grateful for. German, English, Russian, Latin … even Japanese and Chinese. He couldn't remember how he came to understand so many languages.
“Who am I?”
He quite naturally retorted with such a question.
“We don't know either”
The others replied. Then they unleashed a torrent of conversation, though they might as well have been speaking to themselves.
“Schicksal”. Our “Destiny”. A secret organisation with a long history. The true masters of the world, the saviours of humanity.

“Honkai”. The “Collapse”. The one calamity that science has yet to explain completely. Since the dawn of civilisation, it has polluted the human world, transforming peaceful creatures into terrifying demons. These monsters or “Honkai Beasts”, in their alien plastic flesh, strike fear into us all.
“Myself”. I, who lost my memory, was the sole survivor of a Honkai event. Its location was Berlin, where it had originated from some multi-storeyed building.
“My body”. Within this fortunate body of mine hides a great secret — for the sake of saving more people, I must accept their plans for experimentation on my body: it is my only option.
One month. Another month. Month after month.
One year. Another year. Year after year.
The young man, code-named “Ω1”, was taken from one laboratory to another, to repeat the exact same thing, over and over again.
To bear the unbearable, suffer the insufferable.
“Please cooperate with us.”
“Please consider it for the sake of humanity.”
“These are unavoidable side effects.”
A flock of lunatic scientists. Saving humanity and what not: it's all just a load of hogwash.
Did you not say that I am a fortunate survivor? Then why do I have to needlessly suffer through such manner of misfortune?
The “humanity” that you repeatedly emphasise, who are they really? Where is your humanity?
There were moments where I really wanted to just die and be done with it.
If it wasn't for that chatterbox who kept checking in on me.
To Ω:

A good October to you. Time flies: this would already be my 22nd letter to you — last time I had finished telling you the story of the Lady Saint. But before I seek new stories to regale, let us first discuss what is happening around us.

I have already heard of the terrible incident in September, and I apologise on their behalf. Well, it just so happens that there is a new laboratory: I anticipate you will be able to transfer to it soon. Whether the circumstances will be more favourable than your previous lab, that I cannot say for certain — because from what I hear, the new person in charge is a lady with a rather “earnest” personality.

However, I must inform you from the standpoint of Schicksal: all the experiments you've been through, have been for the continued survival of a certain species on this planet, one so-called “Homo sapiens” — hence your continued and necessary suffering. The world will always treat some people unfairly, and this is something none of us can really change.
It has already been three years since the disaster in Berlin. The city has already begun its reconstruction. The people will slowly forget the horrors of that night.

Yet we all know that, at this present moment, a sinister power continues to grow and fester within the rift of space-time. It spared you back then, but it did not spare the others. If we are able to truly fathom the logic behind this phenomenon, then we “Homo sapiens” will be able to live up to our name, to use our sapience to conquer the natural world — then no one will ever need to spend another day living in fear or delusion, deceiving themselves and others.

Yes, this is most unfair to you; in fact the most recent events have been particularly unjust to you. But if only for my sake, I hope you can understand and forgive everything. The fate of all humanity, in a certain sense, rests upon your shoulders.
P.S.

Concerning your background before your memory loss: as far as I know, the relevant department should still be looking into this — but as you may already recognise, it has been more than three years since the incident, and the possibility of getting any results will only become slimmer with time. But I don't believe that so-called “Child of Honkai” Theory. You can't be a Herrscher, right?

Perhaps the arrival of new technology will bring about some unexpected turnaround of the whole situation … who knows? The new laboratory really isn't that bad; in fact, I believe when you get there you'll be quite willing to cooperate with them — trust me.
Your old pal，
Clown Alpha

scene.speak: 唉…这家伙，说得倒轻松…
不过…人家也有人家的难处吧.
毕竟只是不知什么大人物安排给我的匿名笔友罢了.
虽然他讲的“圣女卡莲”的故事还真打动到我了.明明自己不打算理睬这种政治宣传一样的东西—
究竟从何时开始，反而期待起了他每月更新一次的故事呢?
呼…
scene.text: “105”.散发着霉味的木门冷漠地敞开着.
这应该就是刚才那个莫名其妙的女孩子让自己过夜的地方吧.毫无生气的亚麻色窗帘，太平间似的墙壁.果然还是这种，实验室惯有的风格—
嗯?这桌上的面包和零食，是给我吃的么?
嚼嚼.
scene.speak: 天啊!这面包切片里夹的是什么?!
怎么能这么好吃啊!
这难以形容的蘑菇清香!
这恰到好处的熏肉味道!
这无法用语言描述的醇厚回味!
怎么能这么好吃啊!
活着真是太好了!

scene.text: 嚼嚼.
嚼嚼嚼嚼.
嚼嚼嚼嚼嚼嚼.
满足地享用了这无上的美味之后，瓦尔特沉沉地睡去了.
翌日—
半夜下了一场暴雨—推开窗户，空气格外清新，让人难以相信这里就是工业革命的发源地.
不远处，几只山雀在枝头叽叽喳喳地议论着地平线上的霞光.
晨曦里，一只不知从何而来的蝴蝶，慢悠悠地爬过窗户的边沿.
scene.speak: 喂.
scene.text: 蝴蝶轻拍了两下翅膀，消失在湛蓝的天空之中.
穿过树丛的阳光洒落在人的身上，青年的心底里好像有什么坚硬的东西在融化开来.
scene.speak: 喂!
scene.text: 难以置信的一个夜晚.难以置信的一个清晨.
自己究竟有多久已经没有享受过，这样一份平和的安宁?
风雨也好，鸟鸣也罢，哪怕是嗡来嗡去的飞虫—
此时此刻，即便有上百分贝的噪音，那也是无所谓的吧…

scene.speak: 喂!!我说你呢!!!
scene.text: 青年感到了来自脑后的一记重击.
眼前好黑…
咦?山雀们怎么飞到了自己的头顶上，还打起了转儿来?

scene.speak: 真是的，你是聋子吗?都叫你几声了!亏我还好心撬门进来.
scene.text: 扎着双马尾的红发施暴者，蛮横地数落着跌坐在地、眼冒山雀的青年.她也穿着白大褂.
scene.speak: …您是?
哈?没人介绍—
scene.text: 话说了一半，双马尾的视线停留在了一个空盘子上.
它静静地躺在房间里唯一的一张书桌上.
双马尾闭上眼睛，全神贯注地把鼻子凑到它上面闻了闻.
scene.speak: 喂!你…你你你不会是吃了什么松露做的东西吧?
松露?
呃…那个盘子里本来装的是面包切片…夹的好像是某种蘑菇…你说的“松露”是一种蘑菇吗?
scene.text: 红色双马尾翻了一个白眼，差点没气晕过去.
scene.speak: 一种蘑菇?你告诉我松露仅仅是“一种蘑菇”?该死，那个笨蛋不会也是这么想的吧!
scene.text: 她发现在空盘子的旁边，还有其他零零碎碎的“可疑物品”.
scene.speak: 啧啧啧啧…金平糖…原子火球…黑巧克力…
怎么会把松露和这些廉价的零食混在一起嘛!
scene.text: 她一边研究着这些糖果，一边顺手剥一些往嘴里丢—直到看见了角落里的某物.
scene.speak: 哦呀?这是什么?欢迎贺卡?
scene.text: 原来如此，卡片的确是不能吃的东西.
scene.speak: 呃啊啊啊啊啊!
scene.text: 窗边的青年突然谵妄地大叫了起来.
scene.speak: …嗯?你抽什么风?
scene.text: 这名青年语无伦次地叫喊着，似乎放弃了内心里的某种尊严.
未几，他投降似的双手抱头，将自己团成了一个球形.
scene.speak: 哼哼…
scene.text: 女青年似乎明白了什么.
scene.speak: 那~我~打~开~看~了~哦?
scene.text: 红发施暴者拿腔作调地，像念广播剧台词一样说道.
恍惚之间，青年的眼前出现了蜡烛和皮鞭的幻影.
scene.speak: “尊敬的Ω1先生：你好.”
“因为不知道你的名字，所以暂且这么称呼，实在是非常抱歉.”
咳咳，对我怎么就从来没这么客气过啊?
scene.text: 她评点卡片内容的样子，活像是那些吃了飞醋的岳父大人.
scene.speak: “从本日起，你已成为帝国研究院42实验室的一员.当然，本实验室与不列颠政府无关，而是由天命总部直接领导的独立机构.”
“与那些配备重型理化设施的实验室不同，我们是基于伽罗瓦分析和图灵仿真的研究机构，不会对你的生活造成可见的影响.”
呼…Ω1，她写这些，你能看懂吗?
“你也许不知道的是，从三年前的那起灾难开始，我就一直在关注着你.”
“作为样本的你.作为生命的你.作为人类的你.某种意义上，你的存在，早已是我的生活中，一个不可磨灭的印记.”
—呃啊啊啊啊啊!
scene.text: 红发施暴者突然失去了理智，谵妄地朝空气中乱挥拳头.
scene.speak: …可恶!可恶!可恶!…这绝对是故意调戏!…绝对是算准了我也会看到!
你!
scene.text: 她并着两根手指，鄙夷地瞪着蜷缩在地的青年.
scene.speak: 你也知道这种文字游戏—这里、这里、这里!这里除了“研究生活”以外，不可能有其他的含义吧?…嗯?!
当…当然了!我、我再怎么样也是昨天才认识她的啊!
scene.text: 可怜的青年，他满脸通红的样子，反而更显得缺乏说服力.
双马尾的视线直得瘆人，仿佛随时能射出死光.
scene.speak: …你这样子念出来，我也是很羞耻的啊!
scene.text: 不敢对视的青年抱住自己的脑袋，破罐子破摔地大喊了一句.
对方用看垃圾一样的眼神又打量了青年一番，随后闭上了眼睛.
scene.speak: 算了，这件事情上就先放过你吧.真敢有什么非分之想，本小姐第一个就阉了你!
噫!

text.p: （前略）
…我知道，才刚刚见面的人，不会有太多说服力.不过，请你相信—在这里，你将体验到崭新的人生.
以美食发誓的，
丽瑟尔·阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦博士

scene.text: 不愉快地看完了卡片的最后一部分内容，不高兴的双马尾终于想起了什么—
scene.speak: 话说，你还不认识我是吧.
scene.text: 青年惊魂未定地点了点头.
scene.speak: 自我介绍的话…尼古拉·特斯拉.叫我特斯拉就行了.
总之，你只需要知道，我也是这个实验室的负责人之一.
你吃下肚的“蘑菇”呢，是我的私有财产，而且很重要.明白?
scene.text: 她没好气地一把揪住青年的衬衫.
scene.speak: 走吧，人都已经在客厅了.
就是那个美食小偷!不然还有谁啊?!
早上好，特斯拉博士—今天的早饭感觉如何?
早上好，爱因—啧.
scene.text: 扯着瓦尔特领子的双马尾，粗暴地咂了咂嘴.
scene.speak: …你这混蛋，倒跟我装得没事一样?
看来腊肠蛋饼合你的胃口.真是太好了.
scene.text: 几乎被指着鼻子抨击的天然卷平静地坐在沙发里，淡然地吃着一块类似酥皮三明治的东西.
scene.speak: 嘛，毕竟油脂充分，能量很足—不对，你不要跟我打岔!
噗.今天也很精神呢，特斯拉博士.
…还不是被你这家贼气的!哼!
家贼?
爱因斯坦博士不明白特斯拉博士在说什么.
不要装傻!那包松露是不是你擅自从我房间拿走的?
scene.text: 天然卷早有预期似的左右摇着食指.
scene.speak: 爱因斯坦博士友情提醒—
—即使特斯拉博士再喜欢去的里雅斯特度假，也不代表那包蘑菇就是特斯拉博士的私有财产.

remark.p: 的里雅斯特是位于意大利与斯洛文尼亚边境上的一座港口城市，曾因是奥匈帝国的主要出海口而繁盛一时，其所属的弗留利地区是松露的主要产地之一.该城也是国际理论物理中心的所在地.
特斯拉是克罗地亚裔美国人，的里雅斯特与她的故乡有着类似的气候.

scene.speak: 你你你你你说什么?这明明是我千辛万苦才买到的东西，有没有搞错!
而且松露不是什么蘑菇!你叫它蘑菇是对它的侮辱!
呼…
scene.text: 天然卷无奈地叹了口气.
scene.speak: 那是用实验室经费买的.当然是公物.有什么问题吗?
…那、那叫借!下次有钱了我会还上的!不要搞错了!
如果特斯拉博士继续坚持错误的主张，爱因斯坦博士将不得不向总部举报这一挪用公款的行为.
scene.text: 特斯拉的嘴角抽搐了几下，最终选择了更换话题.

scene.speak: 这家伙把自己反锁在卧室里发呆，害得我还以为他要闹自杀呢.
呃…谁要自杀啦!
谁要?你知不知道我敲门敲了多少声?啊??
更别提你还有抑郁症病史?!
抱歉…一时出神…
原谅他吧，特斯拉博士.是你太紧张了.
scene.text: 爱因斯坦舔了舔指尖上的盐粒.
scene.speak: 啧.你们俩倒是一唱一和…难道是失散多年的夫妻?
scene.text: 双马尾的眉头拧成了一个“山”字.
scene.speak: 爱因斯坦博士不会找这么差劲的男朋友的.
嗯嗯就是—不对!我哪里差劲啦!
自暴自弃.
人没有工作就容易自暴自弃.
scene.text: 天然卷少女“嚯”的一声从沙发窝里站了起来.
scene.speak: 所以我们决定给你一份工作.
…工作?
实验室助理.
…助理?我—
总而言之，你不再是小白鼠了.你现在是我们的伙伴.来高兴吧.
scene.text: 双马尾用棒读佛经般的腔调说道.
scene.speak: 特斯拉博士，我们需要正确地告诉他具体职责.
嗯…简单来说，就是伺候我们开心?
比如给我们端茶送水啦，做饭洗衣服啦，没事擦擦地板刷刷马桶啦…
咳咳.
scene.text: 天然卷故意清了清嗓子.
scene.speak: 开玩笑啦!像你这种呆头呆脑的小白脸，想给我们当佣人，我们还不要呢…
咳咳.
scene.text: 天然卷用更响的声音清了清嗓子.
scene.speak: 好啦好啦我会好好解释的啦!明明平常都没有这么啰嗦…
scene.text: 双马尾无奈地戴上了一副不知从哪里摸出来的红框眼镜.
scene.speak: 嗯哼…小白脸给我听好.一般来说，实验室助理当然是帮忙做实验的.可是你显然没有这种能力吧?
scene.text: 青年点点头.
scene.speak: 不过呢，我们觉得你可以提升我们的工作效率.而且这也对你自己有好处.
scene.text: 青年茫然地歪了歪头.
scene.speak: 你的工作是规划我们的休息日.安排好我们的闲暇娱乐.省下我们好不容易放假了却还要去思考玩什么的脑子.
当然，你自己也可以参与其中.听起来不坏吧?
有什么我没有解释清楚的吗?再说得简单一点，你的工作就是带我们玩.
不过工作时间可别来打搅我们.自己去图书馆呆着，或者在周围随便转转—
—别跑太远了搞得组织以为你要逃跑就成.我们可不想和那些便衣多打交道.
喂!行不行啦?不同意的话，我们可就要把你送回去了啊?!
嘿!你傻了?
scene.text: 红框眼镜无奈地在青年的眼前晃动着手掌.
scene.speak: 爱因斯坦博士认为，瓦尔特只是对此感到难以置信罢了.
…丽瑟尔!你是《魔戒》里的兽人吗?不要再故意用这个博士、那个博士来回称呼啦，很烦耶!

remark.p: J·R·R·托尔金的《魔戒》(The Lord of the Rings)于1954年7月29日在英国出版了它的第一部《护戒同盟队》.
托尔金原计划将已经完稿的《魔戒》集结成一册出版，但由于战后物资紧张、纸张短缺，该想法未能付诸实现.

scene.speak: …等等.
…“瓦尔特”是谁啊?
…这个小白脸吗?
…丽瑟尔!不会是你专门给取的名字吧?
等等，谁是小白脸啦!
